summary: This is a forwarded email from September 17, 2019, discussing whether Deutsche Bank (DB) filed any Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) on Epstein-related accounts prior to recent investigations. The response indicates no significant filings were known at that time.

persons.name: Co-Chief, Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit
persons.role: Co-Chief of the Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit at the U.S. Attorney's Office
persons.context: The recipient of the forwarded email, based at the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, inquiring about SARs filed by Deutsche Bank on Epstein-related accounts.

events.title: Email Inquiry Regarding Deutsche Bank SARs on Epstein
events.description: An email exchange discussing whether Deutsche Bank filed any Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) on Epstein-related accounts prior to recent investigations.
personsInvolved: Co-Chief, Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit

locations: One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The document is an email from September 17, 2019, discussing Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) related to Epstein accounts at Deutsche Bank.
The inquiry was directed to the Co-Chief of the Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
The response indicated no significant SARs filings by Deutsche Bank on Epstein-related accounts were known prior to recent investigations at that time.
The document suggests ongoing investigation into financial activities and potential money laundering related to Jeffrey Epstein.
The correspondence highlights the involvement of major financial institutions like Deutsche Bank in the Epstein case investigations.
